claim: A subsequent surgical debridement was performed (Fig 1) during which sampled tissue was subjected to further microbiological testing, including being sent for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) stain and mycobacterial culture.
title: Fig 1. Dorsal necrotic ulcer to fourth digit.

claim: An X-ray of the affected finger confirmed changes consistent with osteomyelitis of the middle and proximal phalanges (Fig 2).
title: Fig 2. X-ray left fourth digit proximal and middle phalanx, showing focal bony lysis and cortical erosion.

claim: A red mark on the inner side of his right upper arm evolved into a small ulcer by late June, suggesting an incubation period of four to five weeks (Fig 3).
title: Fig 3. Dry, small ulcer on the inner aspect of the right upper arm.

claim: The core genome tree distinctly delineated the Batemans Bay isolates, setting them apart from the clinical isolates in Victoria in their own clade (Fig 6).
title: Fig 6. Phylogeographic analysis of Batemans Bay isolates in the context of the population structure of M. ulcerans in south-eastern Australia.
caption: A maximum likelihood phylogenomic tree of M. ulcerans isolates was estimated using core genome SNPs, with branch lengths corresponding to SNP distances. The tree illustrates the clustering of isolates, with isolates from Batemans Bay and Far East Gippsland forming a distinct cluster. The lineage harboring the Batemans Bay and Far East Gippsland isolates traces back to the south-eastern Australian M. ulcerans most recent common ancestor, before branching out towards isolates from the more western localities of Gippsland, Phillip Island, and the Port Phillip Bay area. Link to the Open Street Map basemap: https://www.openstreetmap.org/#map=7/-36.752/144.278; link to the Open Street Map copyright and license information: https://www.openstreetmap.org/copyright.

claim: Notably, the isolates from Batemans Bay and Far East Gippsland are situated on a distinct branch of the phylogenetic tree, which merges at the most recent common ancestor of M. ulcerans in south-eastern Australia (Fig 6).
title: Fig 6. Phylogeographic analysis of Batemans Bay isolates in the context of the population structure of M. ulcerans in south-eastern Australia.
caption: A maximum likelihood phylogenomic tree of M. ulcerans isolates was estimated using core genome SNPs, with branch lengths corresponding to SNP distances. The tree illustrates the clustering of isolates, with isolates from Batemans Bay and Far East Gippsland forming a distinct cluster. The lineage harboring the Batemans Bay and Far East Gippsland isolates traces back to the south-eastern Australian M. ulcerans most recent common ancestor, before branching out towards isolates from the more western localities of Gippsland, Phillip Island, and the Port Phillip Bay area. Link to the Open Street Map basemap: https://www.openstreetmap.org/#map=7/-36.752/144.278; link to the Open Street Map copyright and license information: https://www.openstreetmap.org/copyright.

claim: The relatively long branch length of the Batemans Bay M. ulcerans genomes, revealed by the phylogenomic analysis, is consistent with—as yet—unsampled genetically diverse M. ulcerans present on other areas of Australia (Fig 6).
title: Fig 6. Phylogeographic analysis of Batemans Bay isolates in the context of the population structure of M. ulcerans in south-eastern Australia.
caption: A maximum likelihood phylogenomic tree of M. ulcerans isolates was estimated using core genome SNPs, with branch lengths corresponding to SNP distances. The tree illustrates the clustering of isolates, with isolates from Batemans Bay and Far East Gippsland forming a distinct cluster. The lineage harboring the Batemans Bay and Far East Gippsland isolates traces back to the south-eastern Australian M. ulcerans most recent common ancestor, before branching out towards isolates from the more western localities of Gippsland, Phillip Island, and the Port Phillip Bay area.
